scenes.location: BRODESS FARM BUCKTOWN, MD CLOVER PATCH
characters: WADE IN THE WATER, WADE IN THE WATER
WHO ARE THOSE CHILDREN ALL DRESSED IN
SELL AS ME AND MY BOYS SEE FIT
OF GOD, YOU HAVE THE RIGHT TO BE FREE
CHILDREN... WADE IN THE WATER, GOD'S
MUST BE THE ONES THAT MOSES LED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 BLACK UNION SOLDIERS are assembled, bayonets pointed the starry sky. A legend tells us this is... South Carolina, 1863 - Two years into the Civil War... A small black woman, HARRIET TUBMAN, 40, addresses the troops. We hear her before we see her...

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Suppose there’s a snake coiled at your feet, and it shoots up to bite you. We catch glimpses of her through their bodies as she pace front of them. Her plain face with its habitual scowl, he eyes alive with passion.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Folks get scared and send for a doctor to cut out the bite. But the snake, he rolled up there and while the doctor cutting, he bites you again, in a new place this time. The doctor makes another cut, the snake spring up and bites again. Finally you realize the snake ain’t gon’ stop til someone kills him. A white commanding officer, COLONEL MONTGOMERY, watches intently as Harriet continues...

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Slavery is still alive. Those rice fields downriver are feeding Rebel troops, with the toil of a thousand slaves still in bondage. Our mission is to free those slaves. We've waited years to be allowed to fight in this war, against our own enslavement. And it will not be won without us! Now is our time! Are you ready to kill the snake? The men shout, YES, their eyes fierce, emotional. Harriet nods in approval. As we watch, she retreats into herself, as if listening to inner music, or voices we can hear. INSECTS CHIRP in an eerie chorus, taking us into... FLASHBACK VISION: A SERIES OF IMAGES - monochromatic, out sync and nightmarish -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO YOUNG BLACK WOMEN in their early twenties, LINAH AND SOPH, faces twisted anguish, as they are ripped away from their family at gunpoint by WHITE MEN and dragged to a Slaver's carriage, where other SLAVES are shackled. Their mother, RIT, wails in grief as-- HORSES'S HOOVES pound, carrying them away, their expressi of despair seared into our memory. The chorus of insects grows louder, until it becomes overwhelming, like every insect chirping at once... We hear A VOICE, eerily presen otherworldly... MINTY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON “MINTY” ROSS (YOUNG HARRIET) mid-twenties, a distinct in her forehead, from a wound long healed. Her eyes flutt A handsome black man, JOHN, 28, is shaking her awake.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Minty! Her eyes open, taking him in... deep brown skin, full lip eyes sparkling with excitement...

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: John... She’s lying in a clover patch in the field. He pulls her her feet and kisses her above her scarred forehead. Minty small and muscular, a foot shorter than John.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Least you ‘member my name. I’m always scared you'll wake up from one a them spells and forgit it.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Johnny, Johnny, Johnny...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Guess what I got, Minty-mine? He pulls a document from his pocket and waves it. Her fac lights up. She grabs for it.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Oh, Lord, is it...? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds it above her head. Minty jumps into his arms. H checks to make sure no one’s looking and then spins her, kissing her deeply. A stolen moment. Minty’s father, BEN, 60, handsome and wiry, stands a disc distance away, letting the lovers have their space. She r to him. MINTY (CONT’D) Daddy! We got it! We got de letter! What it say, John? Read it to me!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Don’t need to, got it remembered. (reciting) “,..I, Joshua Abrams, having reviewed the original last will and testament of Atthow Pattison..." As Minty walks away between Ben and John, their voices ar lost beneath a louder, soulful voice, singing...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: SLAVES, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: SLAVES, (PRELAP)
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plantation house is situated scenically in fields of wh and corn. 20 Slaves are gathered in front of the wide veranda where... REVEREND GREEN, 55, black, is leading them in a slave spiritual.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: Keep your hand on the plow and hold on! Wanna get to heaven I'ma tell you how; Keep your hand on the gospel plow. Keep your hand on the plow and hold on! Amongst the slaves are Minty, John and Ben, along with ot members of the ROSS FAMILY; Ben’s wife, “RIT,” 57, fierce emotional; (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: their children, ROBERT, 32, tall and muscular, BEN JR “JUNYAH”, 26, HENRY 18, and RACHEL, 20, heavily pregnant with a toddler in hand. All singing with mournful passion

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: SLAVES
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: SLAVES
dialogues.text: Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: Keep you hand on that plow and hold on! Keep you hand on that plow and hold on! EDWARD BRODESS, white, 46, watches from the porch of the house with his wife, ELIZA, 44; his son, GIDEON, 26, hand with piercing eyes; twin boys, VINCE and VICTOR, 12, anda girl of 10, BECKY.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: I leave you today with these words, from Colossians 3:22.... “Slaves, obey your earthly masters in everything, and do it, not only when their eye is on you and to curry their favor, but with sincerity of heart and reverence for the Lord.” Amen.

dialogues.speaker: SLAVES
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: Amen. Thank you, Reverend Green for those wise words. (to the slaves) You folks enjoy your Sunday. Cook has gravy for your cornpone tonight. As Green moves off and the slaves disperse... ON MINTY - still praying, forefingers pressed to the dent her forehead. John nudges her. She slowly comes back to t present, catching Ben’s eyes. The Ross family confers briefly, with furtive glances to whites on the veranda.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m coming with you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robert, no. You too hot-headed.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I’m coming. Rit stops him, a hand to his chest...

dialogues.speaker: RIT
dialogues.text: Dey beat you again, dey gon’ kill you. Go wit Mary. Robert's wife, MARY, waits for him anxiously. Reluctantly joins her and his brothers heading back to the cabins, as Minty, John and Ben peel away from the others and approac the veranda of the house. Brodess looks up at them, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Massa Brodess, can we git a word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brodess waves them forward. John, Ben and Minty step onto the veranda. Rit stands back, keeping her distance. Eliza looks on from the doorway. Gideon leans against a pillar, arms crossed, eyes on Minty. She trembles as Ben steps up hat in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Massa Brodess... I think you know Minty’s husband, John, who works with me over at Thompson Mill...

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: Course I know him. I let him marry her. What’s your point?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Suh, me and Minty, we thinking bout having a family... and we want our babies born free. So we hired a lawyer... Brodess barks a laugh, looking from John to Ben.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: You hired a lawyer. Ben, what the hell is this nigger talkin’ bout? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, suh, we talkin’ bout the last wishes of your great-grandfather, Atthow Pattison. He gave my wife, Rit, to your mama as a chil’, but she s’posed to be freed at 45. She 57. Rit always knowed bout the will - her mama tol’ her when she was jus a chil’ - so when Minty and John got married, well... we hired a lawyer to dig it up... Brodess is quietly irate. He turns to his wife.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: Hear that, Eliza? We got lawyer-hiring niggers right here. You got this will? John pulls out the letter.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Got a letter from the lawyer, suh. He say it’s clear - your great-granddaddy meant for Minty’s mama to be freed at age 45, ‘long with her children. Brodess glares at Rit. She glares back, tears in her eyes Minty steps up, summoning her nerve.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Mama was 46 when you sold my sisters. Lawyer say dat illegal. We all s’posed to be free when she turn 45. My sisters is lost to us, but John and me, we wan’ our babies born free, like dey s’posed to! Brodess snatches the letter from John, glaring at Minty.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: How you know, Minty? You learn to read?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: No, suh. John read it to me. Brodess glares at John and then puts on his glasses and reads... He looks up at them.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: How you niggers save enough to pay a lawyer in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I worked some extra hours for Thompson. Took near two year. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza looks from Ben and John to Minty, outraged.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: You have the gall to stand here and tell us you been plotting against us for two years? Brodess tears up the letter. The blacks are stricken. He balls up the torn paper and tosses it to Gideon.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: Make her eat it. Gideon takes a hold of Minty’s face and forces the paper her mouth. Their eyes meet as she gags.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Minty) Now you listen here, girl. Your daddy may be free and your husband too, but you and your mama, your brothers and sisters - belong to me, for life. Your babies will belong to me, and their babies, TO USE OR

dialogues.speaker: UNDERSTAND ME
dialogues.text: Ben and John watch, shaking with rage. Rit starts to cry, unleashing decades of emotion.

dialogues.speaker: RIT
dialogues.text: You a devil! You a devil, Edward Brodess! You sold my daughters south, where nobody know dey name! My babies lost, and nobody know dey name! She sobs. Brodess looks from Rit to Minty.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS
dialogues.text: I may have to sell this one too, Rit. Can’t have this kind of mischief round here. But don’t worry about Minty, she’s strong. Strong enough to pick cotton. Now git off my damn porch! John puts an arm around Minty and steers her away. Ben follows. Brodess shouts after them...

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John, you and Ben ain’t welcome here no more! I don’t want you near my slaves, lest you spread your contagion! STAY OFF

dialogues.speaker: MY PROPERTY
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brodess falls back in his chair, mottled and gasping. He glares at his son.

dialogues.speaker: BRODESS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Weren’t for you, I’da sold that girl years ago. Gideon goes after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben supports a sobbing Rit. John tries to comfort Minty. takes her face and kisses her hard. Gideon pursues them.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: John, you heard my daddy! You and Ben get on back to Thompson's. The men wrench themselves away from their wives and head toward the gate. Minty glares at Gideon. She runs off, into the woods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty collapses in front of an enormous poplar tree by a creek, crying, praying fervently.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: My massa an evil man, Lord! You know he evil. Dear Lord, if you cain’t change his soul, take him! TAKE HIM, LORD! A chill runs up her spine and she turns... Gideon is standing not far away, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Lord don’t listen to niggers, Minty. I been tellin’ you that since we was kids. Minty faces Gideon. A cool breeze raises goose bumps on h arms.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Since that time I had Typhoid as a boy and mama had you sit with me. First thing I saw when I opened my eyes, was your little black face, hair sticking up every which way. Praying. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared the fever right outta me. I got used to your face, but that praying always made my skin crawl. He gives a rueful laugh, full of complicated emotions.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the hell were you thinking, hiring a lawyer? Did you think daddy would just let you and your family free - damn near half his property - just like that? She is turned half-towards him, her face impassive. He studies her.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Daddy warned me, “Boy, having a favorite slave is like having a favorite pig. You can feed it, play with it, give ita name, but one day you might have to eat it or sell it. You know it, and the pig knows it. If you have to sell it, there’s no more guilt than separating piglets. And if you have to eat it, you'll forget its name.” He looks at her, full of complicated emotions.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope one day I forget yours. C’mon home, Minty. He turns and walks back towards the farm. Minty’s chest rises and falls, her feet refusing to follow. Gideon turn back.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C'mon, I said. Minty stumbles after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty is sleeping. Her eyes open. A second later, we hear ELIZA’s SCREAM-— As Eliza continues screaming, the other family members st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slaves come out of their cabins and look in the direction the big house, Eliza’s distress coming from within... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He’s dead! Oh, God, he’s dead! ON MINTY, horrified...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few gravestones on a shady patch of lawn. Minty, Rit and Rachel stand with the women, children and elderly Brodess slaves at a fresh gravesite on the proper as the Ross brothers and male slaves lower Brodess’s plai coffin into the earth. A WHITE MINISTER mumbles gloomy wo to the neighboring farmers and family friends in attendan Eliza is with her children, face swollen from crying, cho with grief. Rit and Rachel keep their eyes downcast, thoughts hidden. Minty prays in earnest, tears streaming. She looks up... Gideon is glaring at her, wounded accusation in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty is chopping lumber, splitting upright logs on a stu muscles rippling with each blow. As she chops, INTERCUT--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GIDEON hammers an AUCTION NOTICE onto trees. He stands ba and reads it, sweat and grief in his eyes. NEGRO FOR SALE On Monday, the 30th of September, a female slave called Minty, about 25 years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MINTY - releasing her emotions on the wood. She upends new log, ax raised against the sky... The sound of insects grows louder... A BIRD in a tree abo her chirps, urgently. Minty faints, embedding the ax in the wood, unconscious o her feet.  11.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY'S VISION -
dialogues.text: (A) DARK CLOUDS race across the sky. (B) A FLOCK OF BIRDS take flight, (C) HORSES break from their restraints and r panicked, flanks straining... The VOICE, otherworldly, present... LEAVE, NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty heaves the ax from the wood with a gasp. She looks around her, panicked... In the distance, the overseer, Foxx, approaches, shading eyes against the blinding sun... Minty drops the ax and e behind the shed. She runs, skirting the outbuildings. She can see Foxx, searching for her... Minty evades him, tearing up a path, colliding with-- JOHN. He holds her, pulling her out of view. She clings t him.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: John! Johnny... I gotta go! I gotta go right now!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I know. We goin’. She looks up at him, confused. He pulls a crumpled auctio notice from his pocket - Negro For Sale.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m coming with you. She touches his face and lips, shaking her head.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: John, you free. Dey catch you, dey gon’ take your freedom. I cain’t live wit dat.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: You won’t make it alone, Minty. Who gon’ protect you, you fall into one a them spells? Who’s gon’ be there when you wake up? You need me. Minty seems to consider this. She kisses him hard.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Wait for me by de gate. I’m gon’ say goodbye to my mama. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John nods. He presses her close.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: We be alright. Hear me? Jes hurry. He kisses her again and dashes off. Minty watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind a barn, Minty peeks out as... The slaves finish their work. Rit rubs her back, sighing the rising moon. The air flickers with dragonflies and moths. Minty begins singing, emotionally....

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I'm going to leave you, Farewell, oh farewell; But I'll meet you in the morning... MINTY’S VOICE floats to the slaves in the fields. Rit is unnerved by her daughter’s choice of song, she looks arou for her as the other slaves join in...

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Farewell, oh farewell! I'll meet you in the morning, I'm bound for the promised land! On the other side of Jordan, Bound for the promised land! Foxx, reassured by the sound of her voice, searches for t source of it, but by now all the slaves have taken up the song, obscuring her. Minty ducks towards the cabins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SINGING continues as Minty throws a few items into a clot and ties it to her waist, tucking a knife into the makesh belt. A pair of worn shoes are side by side near her mother’s pallet. Minty takes the shoes and puts them on h bare feet. With the knife, she draws a heart in the dirt floor where the shoes were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SINGING continues as Minty sprints to the edge of the pat where she sees... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN, half-hidden in the trees near the gate, waiting for anxiously. Eyes shining with tears, Minty wrenches her eyes away fro him and takes off, in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty runs lightly through the woods as the moon rises. EXT. BRODESS FARM —- EDGE OF PROPERTY - NIGHT - MINUTES L John comes out of his hiding place and scans the growing darkness for Minty, chest tight with worry. He heads back towards the gate. We hear HORSE HOOVES approaching... John is trapped with no place to hide as Gideon rides up.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: What you doing here, John? We don’t want your kind here! John raises his hands, submissively.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Come to kiss my wife, is all, suh. Sho is hard not bein’ able to see her.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: You better get used to missing her, John. In fact, if I was you, I'd find another wife. Now git yourself back to Thompson's Mill.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (bristling) Yes, suh. John turns and starts away, holding his breath. He walks few paces... We hear the thunder of hoofbeats as Foxx rides up, on horseback.

dialogues.speaker: FOXX
dialogues.text: Gideon!

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FOXX
dialogues.text: Minty! She gone! (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon raises his gun, aiming at John’s back.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Stop right there, nigger! John turns around. Gideon and Foxx corner him.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is she? Where’s Minty?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I tol’ you, I was just comin’ to see her-- Gideon takes his riding crop and STRIKES him across the f John falls to the ground, blood in his eyes. EXT. THOMPSON’S MILL —- POPLAR NECK - NIGHT A mill by a man-made waterfall, surrounded by stacks of lumber. Minty skirts around it towards a scattering of small cabi INT. THOMPSON'S MILL - BEN’S CABIN - NIGHT The modest cabin is decorated with wood carvings and hand crafted figurines. Ben takes off his boots painfully. He rubs his knees. There’s a knock; Minty’s face at the window. Ben glances then immediately turns away. He opens the door, avoiding face.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Don’t wanna look at ya. Wanna say I ain't seen ya. I can see your heart.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Daddy, dey gon’ sell me down river, where nobody come back from. I gotta run. Ben turns away, packing a small sack with biscuits and ya

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Listen here, gurl - you go to Rev Green church, ask him to pray for your journey. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: But... Reverend Green always preachin’ obedience... Ben turns to her sharply, still avoiding her face.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Do what I say. Go to Rev Green church, ask him to pray for your journey.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Yes, daddy. He hands her the sack, then goes to a shelf where small figures of his wife and children have been lovingly craft from wood. He picks up the one of himself and presses it into her hand. Her hand covers his. They stand there a moment, hands clasped together.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Just know I’1l be with you.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: I love you, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I love you too. A sob is stuck in his chest, the strain of not looking at proving too much for him. BEN (CONT’D) Go on, then. Minty tucks the figure into her pocket and kisses him. Sh walks out the door... EXT. BEN ROSS’S CABIN - NIGHT - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Minty! Ben steps out, points in the sky towards the Big Dipper.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t forgit the Big Dipper. Pointer stars in the cup point directly to the North Star. Follow the North Star.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Yes, daddy. I love you. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty turns and runs. Ben stands silhouetted in the doorw eyes dropping to the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty runs, using the stars to get her bearings... EXT. REV. GREEN’S CHURCH - NIGHT Minty approaches a clearing in the woods. Rock formations marking the graves of slaves and freedmen, cast shadows i the moonlight. A small wood building with a rough hewn cr rises beyond the graves. The church is dark. Minty tries the door. It’s bolted shu She bangs on it... We hear noises from inside.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Minty, Ben Ross’s daughter. Rev Green opens the door and pulls her in quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bolts the door behind them. It’s dark in the church an Green is in a dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: Girl, what are you doing out here alone at this hour? Have you lost your mind?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: My daddy say ask you to pray for my journey. There’s a shift in Rev Green’s demeanor. He lights candle

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: You the one wit the spells?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: ..-Yes, suh. He turns to her, the candle illuminating his skepticism.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: And you intend to run. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Dey gon sell me south, way from my husband an family...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: Which means they motivated. You money ta them. Unless word spreads you run off, then you damaged goods. They’1ll make you pay for that - beat you, hobble you, or worse. You go alone, you got a hare’s chance in a fox grove. If the slavers don’t get you, timber wolves and copperhead will. Can you even read, child? Minty shakes her head. He sits her on a bench and sits beside her.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe nobody noticed you gone. Maybe you can sneak back ‘fore daylight. Minty looks up at him, suddenly fierce.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: I ain’t goin’ back. I wan’ be free! The power of the words stuns Minty - words never spoken. reverend nods solemnly. His manner businesslike.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: There’s not much time. It’s near midnight. You must be miles away from here by dawn. I need you to remember what I tell you. Can you do that? Minty nods, determined, trying not to be overwhelmed.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fear is your enemy. Trust in God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty runs through the woods. She stumbles, picks herself and runs again.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Keep the Choptank River to your left and the North Star ahead. If there are no stars, just keep following the river. If you can’t see the river - listen for it. You know moss grows where its dark and wet - wet points to the water. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the trees we see the Big Dipper. Beyond it, the Nor Star. A river glitters in the moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Follow the Choptank to its headwaters in Delaware. When the river splits, cross the rushing creek to your left and head straight North. Minty squats peeing. The moon’s reflection is caught in a brackish pond. The woods are alive with sound.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (OVER)
dialogues.text: In a few day’s time the Delaware River will be on your right. Follow it to Wilmington, look for a blacksmith and iron merchant named Thomas Garrett. I’11 send him word. She finishes and takes off again, running lightly over tr roots and fallen limbs.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN, (OVER)
dialogues.text: May God be with you! EXT. THOMPSON’S MILL - NIGHT ON BEN - mournful and sincere.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I ain’t seen her, suh. Ain’t looked on my daughter’s face since Massa Brodess run us off. Gideon and Foxx face Ben and his boss, the owner of the estate, A.C. THOMPSON, 50s. John stands bleeding between them, face split from the whip. Gideon is irate.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: A.C. THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Ben’s an honest nigger, Gideon. He says he ain’t seen her, he ain't. Gideon approaches John, full of menace.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: This one knows something. Caught him sniffin’ round the cabins just when Minty ran off. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I tol’ you, I ain’t seen her! Thompson steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: A.C. THOMPSON
dialogues.text: Nephew, this is uncalled for! These men are my respected workers! I will not have them further injured! The two white men face off, Thompson richer and more powerful, Gideon a head taller and decades younger.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: If your niggers helped my slave escape, I’m holding you responsible. So if you don’t want me taking this personal, uncle, why don’t you send some of your men to help me bring her back? Gideon and Thompson glare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty lies asleep on a bed of pine needles, hidden agains ridge. Suddenly she’s jarred awake by a tidal wave in her soul... A PRAYING MANTIS seems to be looking at her intently. We hear THE VOICE: QUIET. DANGER. We hear DOGS and VOICES... Minty doesn’t dare move... A PATROL of men on horseback, approaching. We hear GIDEON VOICE.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Morris, you and Butch stay to the roads, Foxx and me will take the woods. The men split off. A SLAVE with hounds on a leash leads Gideon and Foxx deeper into the woods, away from her... Suddenly the dogs seem to catch a scent and go veering in direction-- ON MINTY - Frozen. If she moves, she risks being seen. Bu she can’t wait for the dogs... Minty takes off, tearing through the woods, pursued close by the dogs, only 50 yards behind her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon and Foxx ride after the dogs, the horses picking t way through the overgrown woods with difficulty.

dialogues.speaker: FOXX
dialogues.text: They got a scent! WE FOLLOW MINTY - as she plows through thickets of trees, branches slapping her face and arms. She trips over the carcass of a possum. She picks it up and hurls it away fr her, sliding painfully into a ravine. She dives under a fallen tree, disturbing a SNAKE, which unwinds itself from a branch above her head and dangles f to face. Minty tries to control her terror as the dogs pa close, going after the dead possum. HORSES’ LEGS, follow, jumping the ravine. Minty keeps her eyes on the snake as she edges out of her hiding place. S runs, in the opposite direction. EXT. WOODS’ EDGE - DAWN Minty catches her breath at a tree line, an enormous clea before her. The North Star shines ahead, faint in the growing light. We can hear the dogs barking behind her, b on her scent. She steels her nerve and runs-- Dashing across the open space, a dark, small figure again the graying landscape. She races for the distant tree lin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty looks back. The wide expanse is clear... then we se the tiny figures of the dogs, followed by Gideon and Foxx with lanterns, converging with the men from Thompson’s Mi They ride towards her, then separate, hoping to head her Minty peels the shoes from her bloody feet and rubs her s and shoes with spruce pine, trying to cover her scent. We hear the dogs, barking in the distance. Minty runs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty drags herself forward, exhausted. She comes to a bridge over a fast moving creek. Minty hesitates... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear HORSES AND DOGS.... She dashes across, looking be her as-- BUTCH and MORRIS, two dangerous looking white men, conver with the dogs on horseback. Minty sprints away from them, but stops short when-- GIDEON appears with Foxx the other side, also on horsebac

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Minty, you devilish girl. Minty eyes the churning water below, the Thompson’s Mill advancing slowly from the other side. Gideon gestures for them to halt. He dismounts, inching towards her.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: C’mon back peaceful. Your family’s worried about you. Your mama’s crying, your sister too. C’mon home. Minty’s eyes flick to the water and back to Gideon. He stops, a few paces away.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You thinking bout jumping? Suicide’s a sin against God - you know that. Against those that own you too. Minty climbs onto the rail. Gideon inches closer. He lean on the rail, several feet away, speaking casually.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've decided not to sell you after all, Minty. You been there all my life - I'd miss your ugly face. I’m gonna have to hurt you a little, to teach you a lesson. But it wont be too bad, long as you come back gentle. C’mon home, Minty. Minty looks him dead in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: I'ma be free or die! In the blink of an eye, she thrusts herself off the rail, into the churning water below. The patrol converges on the bridge. Gideon watches in hor as the current pulls her away and under.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Minty!!!  22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon, Foxx and the dogs search the river’s edge. Down river, Morris shakes his head and draws a hand across his neck. She must be dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty wakes, sprawled at the edge of the river bank. She pushes onto her hands and knees, vomiting water. After a moment, she crawls to her feet. Her shoes are gone, along with her head wrap, the knife, everything but her tattere dress, which hangs indecently from her battered body. She searches frantically in her pocket for the figurine o her father, giving a sob of relief when she finds it. Barefoot, hair wild, she trudges off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty runs through wide open farmland, exposed in the afternoon light, searching desperately for a place to hid She sees... A FARM HOUSE in the distance. Another across the road, fi hands with the cattle, slaves working the fields. Minty sees a farm cart, covered with a tarp. She sprints towards it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart is piled high with wheat and hay. Minty crawls beneath the tarp and tucks herself between bales of hay. She rests. Her breathing slows, her eyes closing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON MINTY - She opens her eyes. The cart is moving! Minty peeks from underneath the tarp...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINTY’S POV - The farm cart bumps along a country road, passing... (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLAVE CATCHERS, heading the opposite direction... THREE RUNAWAY SLAVES tied together in the back, passing close enough to see their despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cart stops. Minty peeks from underneath the tarp... The farmer dismounts. He looks up at the stars. He speaks softly, almost to himself.

dialogues.speaker: FARMER
dialogues.text: I know you're there. I’m heading to market, just up the road. Best get out now. Minty jumps from the wagon and darts into the trees. She watches as the farmer climbs on his horse and drives off. The sky breathes with dawn’s first light. Minty finds the North Star and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is just clearing after a downpour. Minty is soake and shivering, hiding at the corner of a tavern near a sparsely populated stretch of waterfront. MINTY’S POV - A WHITE COUPLE kiss in front of the tavern, feet away. Minty looks past them to... A BLACK BOAT WORKER docking his skiff. As the couple moves off, Minty makes a dash for the river approaching the black boatman.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Suh... You know a blacksmith round here, name of Garrett? The boatman, JASPER MARLEY, looks down at the tiny figure the drenched, torn dress. He quickly whips off his rough cloak and throws it around her shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Careful, girl. You half dressed, look half dead. Anyone with eyes can see what you are. The man you looking for is on the corner of 4th and Shipley. No more than half a mile west. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty pulls the cloak around her. It drags the ground. Sh looks up into the sailor’s rough, worried face.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Thank you, suh. She staggers off. Jasper watches with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THOMAS GARRETT, a youthful and robust white man in his fifties, dressed plainly in the manner of the Quakers, polishes a set of fire irons, an assortment of ironworks display around him. He hears a rustling and looks up, jumping as he sees Mint shrouded in the dripping cloak, like death itself.

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: May I help thee, friend?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Suh... You know a Negro name Reverend Green?

dialogues.speaker: GARRETT
dialogues.text: Yes, I do. I’ve been waiting for thee. Minty collapses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty wakes in a strange bed in a plain room. She’s in he underclothes. She sits up, alarmed... Across the foot of the bed is a plain chocolate brown dre On a table next to her bed sits her father’s CARVED FIGUR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MINTY’S BARE BANDAGED FEET pad down a corridor. The dress too short and comes high above her ankles. She hears voic below and tentatively starts downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas Garrett sits at the head of a long table, laden wi food. His wife, RACHEL GARRETT, looks up as she sees Mint She’s very plain, with a kind smile. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL GARRETT
dialogues.text: I couldn't mend your dress I’m afraid. T’was too far gone. What you’re wearing was our Amy’s favorite. She’s with the Lord, and has no use for it. But she would approve. I found something in the pocket of your dress which I put by your bed. It looked important.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Minty looks at them, timidly. They’re both emotional.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT
dialogues.text: Well. Come down. You must be hungry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minty sits at the table with Rachel and Garrett. Garrett holding forth, while Rachel watches him, indulgently.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT
dialogues.text: You're not the first to sit at our table, confused and hungry - far from it! Helping fugitive slaves is my divine duty and my life’s work. Why, I almost lost this house just last year, when I was sued in federal court for aiding slaves. After being tried, convicted and heavily fined, the judge asked me if I’d learned my lesson. I said to the court. “If thee knows of any slave who needs assistance, send him to me, for I now pledge to double my diligence in assisting slaves to freedom!” He laughs robustly. Rachel smiles and pats his hand. He takes a bite of pork, peering at Minty, bright-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So tell me, friend, how did thee find the courage to come all this way alone?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: T'was de Lord. I think God wan’ me be free.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT
dialogues.text: My dear child, I believe that God means all mankind to be free. Minty looks at him in wonder. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Suh... you a saint?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT
dialogues.text: No, friend. I’m a Quaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse-drawn carriage drives across a broad plain as sun tinges the horizon pink and gold. Garrett drives the horses, wearing the broad-brimmed hat cloak that distinguishes the Quakers. He brings the carri to a stop, climbs down and opens the back. Minty gets out, half hidden by a wide Quaker hat.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT
dialogues.text: Here we are, friend! The Pennsylvania border. Shall I drive thee across, or would thee prefer to walk into freedom alone, on thy own feet?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: (overwhelmed) I‘11 walk with de Lord. Minty gives him back the hat and cloak. She still wears h daughter’s plain brown dress. He regards her fondly.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT
dialogues.text: Then this is where I’ll leave thee. It’s 25 miles to Philadelphia. Find the Pennsylvania Antislavery Society and ask for William still. He reaches in his cloak and presses a daguerreotype of a handsome black man into her hands. Minty looks at it in wonder.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS GARRETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is his likeness, so you'll know him when you see him. Until we see each other again, God bless thee.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: God bless you, suh. A small sign marks the Delaware-Pennsylvania border. As Minty walks past it, the sun rises, bathing the countrysi in light. Minty looks down at her hands to see if she’s changed. She spins around in the field, exuberant.  27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bustling city of Philadelphia. A carriage passes, revealing Minty. She looks around her in wonder. BLACK VENDORS roast oysters, chestnuts and corn, or peddl matches and flowers to fashionable WHITES. Minty feels conspicuous, fighting the urge to duck when whites look her way. She approaches a VENDOR.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: “Please, suh... I lookin’ for de Pennsylvania Antislavery Society.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR
dialogues.text: Corner of 5th and Arch Street, bout half a mile down. He looks her over, realizing.

dialogues.speaker: VENDOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (he lowers his voice) Don't be afraid, there plenty of us here in Philadelphia. Walk like you got a right to, won’t nobody pay you no mind. Minty nods gratefully and continues on, trying to walk li she’s got a right to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINTING PRESS - A pamphlet is being copied. WILLIAM STILL, 28, black and dashingly handsome, carefull pulls a pamphlet from the press, the ink still wet. He ha it up to dry next to others on a rack. The pamphlet is titled, ANTI-SLAVERY REFORM. Minty enters. William peers through the pamphlets.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: May I help you? She checks the daguerreotype against the man in front of

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Suh, are you Mr. William Still?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: I am. And you are...? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: (she hesitates) ...-A white man name of Garrett sent me. A beat. William looks at her with clinical interest.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Please, have a seat. William leads her to a chair by a desk. He disappears int back room and returns a few moments later with a cup of w and a weathered copper case, from which he removes a marb NOTEBOOK. He puts the cup in front of Minty and opens the book, dipping a pen in ink. Minty drinks the water, gratefully. WILLIAM STILL (CONT’D) What is your full name and where are you from? She hesitates. He tries to put her at ease. WILLIAM STILL (CONT’D) This book is full of fugitive slave histories. I keep a record of most of the slaves that come through Philadelphia. Some I have to find, most find me, as you have.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: My name Araminta Ross Tubman. Folk call me Minty. I come from Dorchester County, Maryland, farm of Edward Brodess.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Edward Brodess is your master?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Massa Brodess dead. His wife, Miz Eliza, own me and my family.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Not you, not anymore. Minty is quiet as she tries to grasp this concept. WILLIAM STILL (CONT’D) Where are the others?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: Weren’t no others. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: You can tell me, Minty. I’m a friend. Who did you escape with?

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: I left my husband an family. T’was jus me, an de Lord. William takes this in, blown away.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: You're... a brave and lucky girl, Minty. I don’t know if you realize how extraordinary it is, what you’ve done. By some near miraculous means, you've made it 100 miles, alone, to freedom. (collects himself) Would you like to choose a new name, to mark your freedom? Many ex-slaves do. Whatever name you want.

dialogues.speaker: MINTY
dialogues.text: (thinking) Dey call my mama Rit, but her name Harriet. I want my mama name, and my husband. Harriet Tubman. We see the name, Harriet, as he writes it in his book. Fr now on, we will call her Harriet.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Very good. So, tell me, Harriet, how would you characterize your master? What kind of man was he?

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: He de devil. Most whites I know is devilish.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Not all of them. Mr. Garrett just got you to me. (back to business) Did your master ever hurt you, physically? Do you have wounds? Scars from beatings? Harriet fingers the dent in her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Overseer crack my head open, when I was bout 13. I was at the store, out at de crossroads, with Massa’s son, Gideon. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Gideon an me was companions when we was young, and I was strong, and could carry a 40 pound bag a rice, so overseer let me go. Harriet frowns, lost in the memory. William watches her, hovered over his book.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: My big brother, Robert, snuck off and followed us - din’ trust Massa Gideon lone in de woods wit me. I tol’ him to go back, but he wouldn’t leave me. Few minutes later, overseer bust in, lookin’ for ‘im - mad as a rabid hound. Robert - he a proud boy - he stand up to ‘im, say his piece. Overseer got so mad, he pick up a weight from the counter an hurl it at my brother... ‘cept I stepped ‘tween ‘em. Crack my skull right open. She fingers the scar. William is spellbound.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dey say I slept most 2 month. Next thing I ‘member, I was seeing my sisters sold.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK VISION -
dialogues.text: The same image we’ve seen before - Harriet's sisters, LIN AND SOPH, faces twisted in anguish, as they are forced in Slaver's carriage. Now we see YOUNG GIDEON, armed with a rifle, helping load them in. HORSES'S HOOVES pound, carry them away.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Cept I saw it before it happen.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (confused) Before it happened.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: God showed me, to prepare me I guess. But when it happen, it hurt so bad, worse den any beating, worse den de hole in my head. Hole in my head jus made God’s voice more clear. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William is stunned. He makes a note in his book: possible brain damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William walks Harriet through town. He walks with confidence. Harriet, still resisting the urge to duck, lo at the whites around her, mystified.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: How you tell de angels from de devils, when dey walking in de street, side by side?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Well, often you can tell immediately, by how they look at you. But sometimes you have to use your intuition.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: You mean, my top eye. Dat’s what we call it. William looks at her, amused and a bit charmed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Yes, your top eye. Harriet looks at the whites, trying to see their souls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and Harriet are walking through an enclave of bla laborers and freedmen. They approach a modest rooming hou and enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William goes to a counter and rings a bell. Moments later beautiful and sophisticated black woman in her thirties, MARIE BUCHANON, comes downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: Mr. Still, good evening.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Good evening, Marie. This is a new arrival, Harriet Tubman. Harriet, this is Marie Buchanon. She is a friend and the owner of this establishment. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: Please to meet you, Harriet. Harriet is shy in front of the elegant woman.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: ...Ma’am. William and Marie exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: I am leaving her in your good hands, Marie. Good evening, ladies. William tips his hat and strides off, leaving them alone. Marie looks Harriet over.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: C'mon in. Marie leads her upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman and two men play cards in a handsome parlor. Harriet looks around at the fine furnishings, overwhelmed Marie watches her, amused.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: Yes, I am a woman, yes, I am Negro, and yes, I own the place. Get your jaw off the floor. My mama was freed when her master died. She was pregnant with me, so I was raised free, here in Philadelphia. You can have the last room on the left upstairs. I’ve served supper already, I'll make you a plate. But first, you need a bath. You stink like a barnyard animal! There’s a wash tub in the kitchen. I’11 put some water on. Marie starts back downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: You was born free. Guess you never had de stink of fear. Of runnin’ fo yo life. Marie stops, turns back, chastened.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: (gently) You're right, Harriet. I have not.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marie carries a pot of hot water from the fire and pours into a copper tub, already half-filled.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: I‘1l warm your plate. You need anything, just let me know. A folding screen separates the tub from the kitchen, offe a bit of privacy. Harriet takes off the dress and underclothes and lets the fall to the floor. She catches her reflection in a piece mirror. A map of scars, both old and new, covers her lean muscular body. Marie catches a glimpse of Harriet’s body as she lowers herself into the bath. MARIE BUCHANON (CONT’D) You got a man? BEHIND THE SCREEN -— Harriet sinks lower in the tub, delighting in the sensual warmth of the bath.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: My husband, John. He free like you. He was gon run wit me, but I’s scared if we get caught, dey take his freedom. So I left ‘im. She watches the dust dance in the fading light.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now I wish he was here wit me. Must’a been hard on him when dey found me gone.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: The boatmen, the “black jacks,” travel up and down the Delaware and Chesapeake Bay. Maybe they can get word to him that you made it. Then he can come to you. Harriet brightens. She sits up, splashing.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Thank you, ma’am. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: Call me Marie. Wash up good. Tomorrow we gonna get you a payin’ job. Harriet grins at the thought. She soaps her hair, vigorously. Then puts her head under the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BROWN HAND polishing wood until we can see reflected... Harriet, in a maid’s uniform, hair tamed, furiously clean Time has passed and she looks healthy and fit, but there’ something manic about the way she works, as if she’s tryi not to think. A tear hits the polished wood. She wipes it away. A young black woman, JESSE, pauses outside the open doorw watching her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Slow down, Harriet. They don’ pay us by the bushel! Seeing her mood, Jesse comes in and helps Harriet make th bed, looking across at her with concern.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come to the social tonight. You might have fun. Would that be so terrible? Harriet doesn’t answer. Jesse looks at her, knowingly. EXT. DOCK —- AFTERNOON Harriet hurries down a narrow street to the river. She’s grown more confident in her manner, no longer fearful. Sh spots a boat worker she knows and waves... It's Jasper, the black sailor she met in Wilmington.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Hello, Miss Harriet!

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Jasper! Any word from my family?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am. Brought some lumber from the Eastern Shore. Your husband and family know you safe. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: My husband send word back?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: No ma’‘am. No word ‘cept what I tol’ you. Harriet turns and walks away, crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet barges into the office, barely noticing... The bustle of people, mostly white, engaged in various activities, passing pamphlets, signing petitions... William, writing at his desk, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Harriet! How are you?

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Mr. Still, I need yo angels to help git my husband an family.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: That’s not how it works, Harriet. My “angels” are part of a sophisticated network, not for your personal use. Trust that we are doing what we can, for who we can. Harriet paces, wringing her hands.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: But I feel somethin’ wrong, William. I cain’t sleep. Please help me!

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Harriet, listen to me! Our work has gotten much more dangerous. Slaveholders are frustrated over the number of runaways. Federal judges, marshals and slave catchers are working together. Even congress is threatening to pass laws to appease the South. He can see that he’s lost her.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: If you won’ help me, I’1l go myself. William is losing patience. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Don’t be ridiculous. I can’t have you risking your life and my network because you're lonely! Rescuing slaves requires skill and careful planning. Can you read a sign, or a map? Can you read at all?

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I put my attention on tryin’ hear God’s voice more clear.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM STILL
dialogues.text: Do you know what would happen if you got caught? They’d torture you, til you pointed them right to this office! You got lucky, Harriet. Be grateful you made it this far and pray for those yet to come. There’s nothing more you can do!

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: (erupting) Don’t tell me what I cain’t do. I made it dis far on my own! God was watchin’, but my feet was my own - runnin’, bleedin’, climbin’, nearly drowned - nothin’ to eat for days an days. An I made it! So don’t you tell me what I cain’t do. You don’ know me! William, watches, stunned, as she walks angrily away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet is with Marie, having just shared her dilemma.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I made up my mind; I’m goin’ back. Wit’out my husband an family, I’m just a stranger in a strange land. If I’m free, dey should be too. I’m gon go git em, one by one, starting wit my husband. I need a suit for him and a dress for me, so I can look like a free lady. Will you help me? Marie goes to the window and looks out, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: I can give you a dress you'll likely be hanged and buried in... She turns back to Harriet, having made her own decision. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIE BUCHANON (CONT’D) Or I can teach you how to wear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet is in a lovely dress and dainty shoes, walking wi her head high. Marie leads her, extending her hands in graceful, ladylike gestures.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: How do you do? Harriet imitates her carriage and gestures with surprisin skill. She’s a natural mimic.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON
dialogues.text: Good. You're confident, composed, but wise enough not to look a strange white man in the eyes. You don’t want trouble. Marie goes to a carved box and retrieves a COLT REVOLVER. She puts it in Harriet’s hands, adjusting her grip from behind. MARIE BUCHANON (CONT’D) But if trouble comes, you’1ll be ready. Harriet looks in the mirror. She aims the revolver, fierc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: off the city streets in a disreputable neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: I‘11 put you in touch with a man who'll sell you free papers. Harriet moves slowly until an UNSEEN MAN whispers to her.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey gal. She hands him money, he hands her papers. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: They won’t be yours - they’re someone else’s. May not match your description exactly, but they’1l get something right. Harriet pushes the papers back to him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Read ‘em for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train chugs through farmland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet sits by a window in a car near the engine room as train heads south. She clutches a satchel.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE BUCHANON, (OVER)
dialogues.text: Hopefully they won’t read ‘em too close. They're more worried about Negroes heading north. Runaways don’t go south. The train pulls into a station.

dialogues.speaker: CONDUCTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dover. Dover, Delaware. Harriet puts her satchel across her shoulders and takes o her papers. She trembles as we follow her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marshals wait to search northbound trains. Harriet sees a group of recently captured RUNAWAY SLAVES shackles. She tightens with fear. A MARSHAL approaches an she turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Hello, suh. How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Papers. Harriet gives him the papers, her back straight and her e below his chin. He eyes at the papers, then her.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dessa Dixon? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Yes, suh.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Where were you born, Dessa?

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Philadelphia, July 18, 1824, of free issue. A deputy approaches. The captured slaves watch the scene unfold. Harriet sets down her bag.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: Says here you're five an a half feet tall. You ain’t more’n five feet.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Musta worn my high boots that day. She smiles. They laugh, unpleasantly. Behind Harriet’s back, her hand grips the handle of the Colt revolver, whi the slaves can see, but the marshals can’t. The slaves watch, on edge.

dialogues.speaker: MARSHAL
dialogues.text: It says you have a birthmark on your forehead. With her free hand she tips her hat back to show her scar

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: That’s correct, suh. They look at her head a moment, then at the papers. A bea The marshal hands them back. Hiding the gun in her dress, Harriet takes them. As she walks away, weak-kneed, the slaves breathe a sigh of reli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet’s brothers, Robert, Junyah and Henry, are raking fields, along with other slaves and their families, prepa for winter planting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon sits at a desk, writing, while Eliza dictates. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Dear Dr. Thompson--No, dear brother-in- law... I hope you will accept this modest payment on the money owed you by my departed--my dearly departed Edward. It has not been easy for me with him gone. He left us in a sorry state of affairs, the depths of which we've only recently discovered. Since you have said you are not in a position to forgive the loan, please accept the enclosed $7.50. I will try to make another payment next month. Your neighbor and sister-in-law, Eliza Brodess. Gideon puts some bills and coins into an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: We're gon’ have to sell some slaves, mama.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Our stature in this community, is measured in negroes. We can’t live like paupers. Who’s supposed to work the fields - the twins?

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Would you prefer to keep the slaves and sell the farm? Eliza turns away from him, sullen.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll sell the Ross brothers. Robert alone is worth 6-7 hundred. If we sell Junyah and Henry too, we can bring home maybe 16. That will go aways to paying off daddy’s debts. You won’t have to beg, the twins can remain useless and we can go on as we have.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: With you unmarried and sleeping in brothels? Gideon and Eliza exchange a loaded look.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: We'll go on as we have. The others will just have to work harder to make up for the loss. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Eliza gives a long, dramatic sigh, gesturing for to begin anew... He takes another sheet.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Negroes for sale...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet stealthily approaches the estate where her husban and father work. She pauses beneath a tree, her excitemen tinged with a sense of foreboding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work is wrapping up for the day and Thompson's workers ar trudging back to their cabins from the mill. John says goodbye to his team and rests against a pile of lumber, exhausted. A VOICE floats to him from the woods.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I had to leave you... Recognizing her voice instantly, John stands and looks around. Harriet springs from the trees by the creek and throws herself into his arms. He clutches her in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Minty... Is it you!? He pulls her out of view into the mill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of them are awash in emotion, touching each other’s face. She’s changed since he last saw her, in proper clot she has the bearing of a free woman. John has changed also. She runs her fingers along the ugl scar down one cheek and across a clouded eye, where Gideo strap made its mark.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Johnny, Johnny... What dey done to you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: One good eye is all I need to see you, girl. You look good, Minty. But why you back here? It ain’t safe. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I come to git you, Johnny, bring you to freedom. I got a suit for you to wear... I been livin’ free, in Philadelphia, but I cain’t live without you. He looks at her woefully. Fear grips her spine.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ain’t you happy to see me?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I heard you was drownt, Minty. Never thought I’d see you again.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I sent you word... by de black jacks...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: By the time I heard you was alive... (a beat; then) Minty... I’m married. She looks at him, confused.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I know you married, Johnny. You married to me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I took another wife, Minty.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: You took another wife...

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Her name Caroline, and she free like me. She carryin’ our chil’. Harriet is floored.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Nother woman carryin’ your chil’? I thought you loved me! Tears spill down her cheeks. He pulls her to him, trying calm her, both of them crying now.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Like I ain’t never loved nobody, not my own kin! You left me, Minty. You went alone and left me and I prayed for you. Gideon whipped the sight out my eye - and I prayed for you. (MORE ) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JOHN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I heard you jumped off that bridge, and I thought you was cold and dead, caught in the river weeds, like some animal - I prayed for you!

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Then you found another wife. He looks at her, wretched. She pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on then. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Minty, you not safe here. You gotta leave, now! Gideon still lookin’ for you.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: So, de white man din’ give up. You did. He backs away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: I love you, Minty. I would’a died for you, if you’d let me. He turns and strides out. Harriet takes a few ragged breaths... She stumbles after him. EXT. THOMPSON’S MILL —- JOHN’S CABIN - DUSK The cabin has a small vegetable garden in front. John was his face and hands in a basin by his stoop. Harriet approaches, unseen. She looks in a window... INSIDE - A lovely woman, round with child, puts aside her work. Hearing her husband, CAROLINE glances at her reflection in a bit of mirror, taking off her head wrap, freeing her springy hair. Harriet pulls the revolver, taking aim at her rival... Then John walks into view, taking Caroline in his arms. H holds her tight, letting her comfort him. Caroline kisses away troubles, not asking their source. He puts his hands her rounded belly. Harriet bends over her knees and vomits. She takes the satchel from her shoulder and slings it hard against the door. She runs, the revolver swinging at her side...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. THOMPSON’S MILL - TREE GROVE - DUSK Harriet runs into the grove of trees, reckless, consumed anguish. She howls, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Why, Lord? I listen for your voice! You tol’ me come, I came! You led me back here! Why bring me all dis way to rub mud in my face? Why you let me live? She contemplates the gun in her hand... The sound of inse grows louder... Harriet arches backwards and falls to the ground, twitchi in spasms. HARRIET'S VISION - A RAVEN stands in front of her. She he THE VOICE: Harriet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A strange dark cloud throws an eerie shadow over HARRIET' BROTHERS in the fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet runs, FEET skimming the earth. Other BROWN LEGS follow; men, women, children...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE RAVEN looks at her. LEAD THEM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet wakes and stands shakily.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: John told me you was here. BEN sits close by, back against a tree, kerchief tied ove his eyes, Harriet’s satchel at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Daddy... He reaches for her and she pulls him to his feet, falling into his arms, heartbreak washing over her. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Johnny don’ love me no more. Ben takes her shoulders, shaking her.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Minty, some things ain’t meant to be. But you here now is a miracle - I got your brothers hidin’ in the corncrib. Miz Eliza fixin’ to sell ‘em. Harriet is sobered by this, realizing the significance of vision... Ben hands her the satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet leads her father to the corncrib.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: They been waitin’ on Robert. Mary’s in labor and he won’t leave her til she delivers. He unlatches the door and Harriet’s brothers - Junyah and Henry climb out.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Junyah... Junyah hugs her tight.

dialogues.speaker: JUNYAH
dialogues.text: Minty! Cain’t believe it’s you.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Henry! Henry’s face lights up as he joins in the hug. JANE, a slender girl disguised as a boy, climbs gingerly the corncrib. Junyah goes to help her.

dialogues.speaker: JUNYAH
dialogues.text: Minty... this my fiancee, Jane. From Horatio Jones farm. Her massa been beatin’ her bad. She comin’ wit us. Henry helps a woman, PHOEBE, 20, with a baby in arms. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Phoebe asked to come too. She scared of bein’ sol way from her baby.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE
dialogues.text: My husband pass last Spring. She all I got. Harriet looks at the infant sleeping in Phoebe’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I hear you made it to freedom, I name her Araminta. Maybe she see freedom too. Harriet takes them in, overwhelmed. She looks at Baby Araminta. Phoebe is desperate.

dialogues.speaker: PHOEBE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She'll be good, I promise. Your sister, Rachel, she stole Miz Eliza’s laudanum, to keep her quiet.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Where is Rachel? Where my sister?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY
dialogues.text: Rachel too scared to run, Minty. She say Miss Eliza got a hawk-eye on her. Harriet turns to her father.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: And mama?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Rit wit me. ANGLE ON - BEN’S CABIN in the distance, where they can se Rit moving slowly about inside. BEN (CONT’D) Miss Eliza let me buy her freedom. Ain’t have much use for her. Rit ain’t been right since she heard you drownt. Her heart would burst, she knew you was here, bout to run again, wit the boys. I’11 take care of your mama. Don’chu worry bout us. Harriet takes in the crew of fugitives, processing. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I planned for one more, not all of you and a baby too. The baby stirs, face bunched in a scowl. Harriet looks at the infant, a stab of fresh pain fortifying her. She take one of the baby’s tiny hands. The baby looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But if you trust me, an follow my lead, baby Araminta will grow up free.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It’s late. You need to go. I’11 send Robert on.

dialogues.speaker: JUNYAH
dialogues.text: What if Mary don’t deliver till sunrise? He’1ll be caught and sold.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: By sunrise, they'll be after you too. This truth sobers them. Just then we see a dark form, streaking across the field towards them. Harriet runs to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Robert! Thank God!

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: Minty! He lifts her off her feet, embracing her. The others surround him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: How’s Mary? Tell us. Robert is breathing hard, from exertion and emotion, maki words difficult.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: We got ourselves a baby girl. Delivered myself, not an hour ago. Set her on her mama’s breast and kissed ‘em goodbye... Phoebe’s baby gives a faint cry. Robert is overcome with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mary’s too weak from childbirth to run, even if I could convince her... I had to leave ‘em. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben reaches for his son’s shoulder. Harriet looks up into her brother’s face, sharing his pai

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: You had to leave ‘em, either free or in chains. You chose freedom. She hands him the satchel. Robert pulls the suit from the satchel and looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: You come for John. I’m sorry, Minty. Harriet shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: I thought I come for him... I see now I come for all of you. Robert pulls off his shirt, revealing a profusion of scar his muscled back, like a network of rivers.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Ain't but a few hours a dark left. If you goin’, you need to go. The siblings take a last look at their mother in Ben’s ca wishing they could say goodbye. EXT. THOMPSON’S MILL - MINUTES LATER Harriet and her brothers lead their blindfolded father to tree-lined edge of the field. Robert is wearing the suit. Ben hugs each of his sons. He kisses his daughter. She clings to him.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: Come wit us daddy.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Me and your mama will be fine. I ain’t goin’ nowhere til all my children free. He touches his daughter’s face. BEN (CONT’D) Git gone, now. I ain’t seen none a you. Harriet leads the freedom seekers off, leaving Ben alone the path. He waits until he no longer hears them, then he lifts the kerchief from his damp eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The freedom seekers follow Harriet through trees. They approach a clearing by a body of water. The baby starts t cry. They freeze. Robert is instantly protective of the child.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: She hungry. She gotta eat. POV - The fugitives sit amongst the trees as Phoebe breas feeds the baby. Someone is watching... We hear a scratchi sound... A DARK FIGURE crouches in the trees, gangly and nappy-hai capturing the scene in a sketchbook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet and the freedom seekers approach through the graveyard. Robert is skeptical. He won’t go further.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERT
dialogues.text: I don’ like dis, Minty. Reverend say der a special place in Hell for runaways. I don’ trust ‘im.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIET
dialogues.text: You trust me? Robert looks at her a beat. Begrudgingly, he nods. Harriet knocks on the door of the church. A few beats lat Reverend Green ushers them in. He takes Harriet by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: It’s good to see you, girl. Heard you'd come back. Almost didn’t believe it. He hustles them into the sanctuary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reverend Green and Henry move aside the pulpit, revealing trap door underneath. Green pulls it up...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: Go on. You’ll wait out the day down there. You’ll be safe.  50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harriet peers down. There’s candlelight coming from below We see FACES, peering up.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND GREEN
dialogues.text: There’s others. Word spread. THREE SLAVES are huddled in the dark - a young man, ISSAC his father, JOE, and Joe’s mother, MIZ LUCY. They look up her, eyes full of fear, uncertainty and hope. Harriet is overwhelmed. EXT. BRODESS FARM — MORNING We hear angry screaming. Slaves in the field look at the house with anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza rages in her dressing gown, smashing plates and vas against the walls by Foxx’s head. He ducks, resigned. Gideon watches his mother’s tantrum, grimly.

dialogues.speaker: FOXX
dialogues.text: We will, ma’am. The twins, Vince and Victor, rush in followed by Becky.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Ma, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: We had five slaves run off.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: 5 slaves - over $2000! This whole farm ain't worth but $5000. We got a rat in our pantry, and it will starve us if we don’t trap it and kill it! RACHEL!! Rachel appears, holding a baby. A brown-skinned girl of four, ANGERINE “ANGER”, trails behind her. Rachel quickly hands Anger her baby brother and looks at her mistress pleasantly.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yessum. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eliza backhands her, sending her into the wall. Anger wai

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: Don’t you “yessum” me, you black bitch! Your brothers run off! Gideon grabs Rachel by the neck and pins her to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: What’s your part in this, girl?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I don’ know nothin’, I swear! I don’ even know what you sayin’! Who run off? He tightens his grip.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: I’1ll snap your neck.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (choking) I... don’... know nothin’. I swear... Gideon releases her. She slides down the wall. He turns towards Anger and the baby...

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Foxx, take these pickaninnies to market and sell ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: FOXX
dialogues.text: Yessuh.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: T’was Minty! Something like hope lights in Gideon’s eyes. Almost tenderly, he takes the squirming baby from Anger’s arms, turning to Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Minty’s dead, you lyin’ wench.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She alive. She come back.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: You seen her?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I hear tell. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FOXX
dialogues.text: Niggers’ tales. Like haints in the marsh. She’s lying!

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: I hope it’s true. Good Lord, I hope it is. Gideon releases the baby into Rachel’s arms. Anger runs t her mother, burying her face in her dress. Rachel clings her children.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Foxx, round up some men and meet me out at Poplar Neck. Foxx nods curtly and runs out. Eliza collapses into angry tears.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZA
dialogues.text: How could your father leave me with his debts and his mutinous slaves?! Gideon goes to his mother.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Hush, Mama, try not to upset yourself. I’m gonna find ‘em for you - Minty too. Rachel, give her a dose of laudanum for her nerves. I’11 deal with you when I get back. Rachel nods, terrified, thinking of the laudanum she gave Phoebe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gideon, on horseback, thunders toward the gate. A BLACK YOUTH steps in his path. WALTER is gangling and nappy-haired, between 18 and 20, dressed in buckskin brit and work boots. Gideon almost runs him over, his horse rearing.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: What the hell is wrong with you, boy! Outta my way!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You looking for some runaways, suh? Gideon circles Walter menacingly. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: What you know about it? Speak up! Walter pulls a beat up notice from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: This here your notice, right? Runaway slave, short, strong, dent in her head. He pulls out a sketch pad and hands it to Gideon. There’s a SKETCH of the slaves convening in the woods, another of Harriet - no longer the same slave girl Gideon once knew, but clearly recognizable as Minty. Gideon looks up from the drawing, eyes burning.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: Where’d you see her?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Take you there, for a dollar. I’ma tracker, I know which way they headed, and I can help you find ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: A tracker, you say?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That and lots more - artist, blacksmith, boatman, carpenter, fisherman, horseman... Got skills right down the alphabet til you get to scout and tracker. Work for wages though - ain’t no slave. Gideon pulls out his gun and aims it at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: GIDEON
dialogues.text: How bout you tell me which way they headed, or I shoot the nose off your face?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: East from Poplar Neck. Gideon throws a coin on the ground. He spurs his horse an rides off. Walter calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know Bigger Long! Gideon pauses, rides back. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Best slave catcher round - but hard to get, ill-tempered and expensive.
